February 9, 2026

How AI Changed the Way I Work

AI Productivity

Six months ago, I started integrating AI tools into my daily workflow. What started as curiosity turned into a fundamental shift in how I approach almost every task.

I'm not an engineer or a data scientist. I'm someone who works with clients, manages schedules, coordinates programs, and handles the thousand small tasks that come with any operations role. But AI has become my secret weapon.

What Actually Changed

Here's the thing nobody tells you about AI: it's not about replacing what you do. It's about amplifying how well you do it.

Before AI, I'd spend 30 minutes drafting a client email, second-guessing every word. Now I can get a solid first draft in 2 minutes and spend my energy on making it right — adding the personal touches, catching the nuances that matter.

Before AI, research meant hours of Googling and reading. Now I can get a solid briefing on any topic in minutes, then go deeper on what actually matters.

Before AI, I'd procrastinate on tasks that felt overwhelming. Now I can break anything down into manageable steps almost instantly.

The Tools I Actually Use

I keep it simple:

  • ChatGPT and Claude — for drafting, brainstorming, research, and problem-solving
  • AI writing assistants — for polishing anything client-facing
  • AI for data — summarizing reports, finding patterns, making sense of numbers

The key insight: AI is a thinking partner, not a replacement for thinking. I still make every decision. I still own every output. But I get there faster and with better raw material to work with.

Why This Matters for Any Role

Every job has repetitive tasks. Every role has moments where you're staring at a blank page. Every professional faces problems they don't immediately know how to solve.

AI doesn't eliminate the need for human judgment — it frees you up to exercise more of it. Less time on the mechanical stuff means more time on the stuff that actually requires a human: relationships, creativity, nuance, and care.

The professionals who thrive in the next decade won't be the ones who fear AI. They'll be the ones who learn to work alongside it.

I'm still learning. Every week I find new ways to use these tools. But the mindset shift has already happened: AI isn't a threat to my job. It's the best tool I've ever had to do my job well.
